thread.title: Ski town eats: Best breakfasts, burgers, barbecue and more
thread.title_full: Ski town eats: Best breakfasts, burgers, barbecue and more

title: Ski town eats: Best breakfasts, burgers, barbecue and more
text:
The signature Red Hut bacon waffle in Lake Tahoe has several whole slices of bacon cooked into its center, with meaty goodness in almost every bite. Larry Olmsted for USA TODAY Fullscreen At the Bake Shop in Girdwood, Alaska, at the base of the Alyeska ski resort, the giant sweet rolls are loved, but it takes a lot of skiing or hiking here to work one off. Larry Olmsted for USA TODAY Fullscreen Served on a cutting board, the Crab BLT at Paramount in Steamboat Springs, Colo., is a monster sandwich of cornmeal-crusted soft-shell crab topped with lots of house-cured bacon, homemade semi-dried oven roasted tomatoes and lettuce. Larry Olmsted for USA TODAY Fullscreen The house signature burger at the No Name Saloon in Park City, Utah, tops a thick bison patty with cream cheese and jalapenos. The onion rings are good too. Larry Olmsted for USA TODAY Fullscreen The signature burger at the High West Distillery in Park City, Utah, is a blend of bison and beef topped with melted gruyere and bleu cheeses and caramelized onions, served with parmesan-dusted fries. High West Distillery Fullscreen An assortment of burgers and chicken sandwiches with delicious fries at Larkburger, a Colorado chain with a location near Vail Village. Larry Olmsted for USA TODAY Fullscreen he specialty at Salt Lake City mini-chain Crown Burger is a cheeseburger topped with heaps of "Greek-style" pastrami, very moist and soaked in broth. Larry Olmsted for USA TODAY Fullscreen The delicious house specialty at Salt Lake City mini-chain Apollo Burger is the Athenian, a char-grilled 1/4-pound patty topped with plenty of feta cheese, roasted red pepper and tzatziki sauce on a home-style bun. Larry Olmsted for USA TODAY Fullscreen The Red Iguana in Salt Lake City serves seven kinds of authentic moles, including Mole Negro, with Mexican chocolate in it, "the King of Moles," shown here with chunks of turkey. Larry Olmsted for USA TODAY Fullscreen Zocalito in Aspen, Colo., specializes in food of Mexico's Oaxaca region, and one of the most delicious dishes is this unusual warm seafood salad with octopus, shrimp, cotija cheese, avocado, cactus and julienned jalapenos over greens and tomatoes. Larry Olmsted for USA TODAY Fullscreen Bin 22 is a tapas eatery set inside a wine store in Wyoming's Jackson, and offers several charcuterie and cheese selections that can be combined into make–your-own appetizer boards. Larry Olmsted for USA TODAY Fullscreen The boneless barbecue rib sandwich at Moe's Original Bar B Que in Vail is awesome. Larry Olmsted for USA TODAY Fullscreen The thick, meaty, juicy and perfectly cooked ribs at Oak in Telluride, Colo., are the runaway barbecue highlight. Larry Olmsted for USA TODAY Fullscreen A Michigan transplant serves up delicious and crusty Detroit-style pan pizza at Brown Dog Pizza in Telluride. Larry Olmsted for USA TODAY Fullscreen While it is sold frozen at gourmet stores nationwide, American Flatbread wood-fired pizza is best at its source in Waitsfield, Vt. Larry Olmsted for USA TODAY Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide The signature burger at the High West Distillery in Park City, Utah, is a blend of bison and beef topped with melted gruyere and bleu cheeses and caramelized onions, served with parmesan-dusted fries. (Photo: High West Distillery)
894 CONNECT 112 TWEET 4 LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE The scene: Summer is finally over, which means ski season is just around the corner, and this is the time of year when travelers start making winter vacation plans. When picking a ski or snowboard destination there are lots of factors to consider, from nightlife to off-slope activities to lodging. But the one thing you know you are going to do every single day of the trip is eat, so it’s important to consider the quality and quantity of ski town dining. This is especially true given the reputation many ski mountains have for high prices and low-quality food on the slopes, so before or after skiing, it is helpful to have great alternatives in town.
Over the past few years Great American Bites has visited many of America’s favorite mountain towns, summer and winter, and has compiled the best ski town eats from coast to coast, for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Ski fare tends to be hearty, and favorites include barbecue, burgers, pizza and big breakfasts, but there are also some surprisingly eclectic offerings to enjoy this winter, from tasty Thai to Oaxacan specialties. And while just about every major ski town offers something good to eat, a few stand out with multiple topnotch offers, most notably Telluride, Colo.; Park City, Utah; and Jackson, Wyo.
Reason to visit: Standout burgers, barbecue, breakfasts and pizza that would all be great even if they weren’t in a top ski town.
The food: The long ski day starts with breakfast, and it is tough to beat the three Lake Tahoe locations of Red Hut Café , on both the Nevada and California sides, popular since 1959. Breakfast portions are enormous, and almost everything is good, but the signature is waffles, uniquely cakey and still using the original recipe from over half a century ago. The most unique offering is the bacon waffle, stuffed with whole slices. Red Hut locations are especially convenient to Heavenly, the region’s largest ski resort, with 28 lifts. Another great morning choice is the Bake Shop , right next to the lifts at Alyeska, Alaska’s largest ski resort, and one that averages nearly twice as much snowfall as most mountains in the Lower 48. The Bake Shop is renowned for its tall, carb-rich stacks of thin, crepe-like sourdough pancakes, with unique flavor and texture, and regulars are also loyal to its addictive and oversized sweet rolls.
USA TODAY
Red Hut Cafe: Hearty breakfast with a side of Tahoe history
USA TODAY
Brilliant Alaska breakfast tempts skiers and cruisers
The Paramount , in Steamboat Springs, Colo., offers one of the best breakfasts in all of skiing — and one of the best lunches, too. In the morning, it’s tough to beat specials like “S@#^ on a Shingle,” first-rate homemade corned beef hash topped with elk sausage gravy, two eggs and fresh-baked biscuits. Other tempting options include stuffed French toast, and “Green eggs and ham,” a skillet filled with eggs and spinach baked over Italian bread covered with house-cured ham, goat cheese and pecan pesto. Breads and sandwiches are exceptional, and the standout corned beef returns at lunch in a killer Reuben, while the Crab BLT and roast turkey are exceptional.
USA TODAY
Great American Bites: Superior ski breakfast in Steamboat Springs
If there’s a food synonymous with après ski, it’s the burger, and while every ski town has them, a few really excel. The bison burgers — the only burgers — at Park City’s No Name Saloon are standout, especially the odd house special, topped with a mound of cream cheese studded with sliced jalapenos. It works. Just down the street at the High West Distillery , which claims to be the world’s only ski-in/ski-out distillery and makes award-winning whiskies, the scrumptious house signature burger is a blend of beef and bison, covered with aged gruyere and bleu cheeses, plus caramelized onions on an artisanal bun, with parmesan-dusted fries. At Empire Burger in Breckenridge, Colo., which also features the highest ski lift in the nation, the large 1/3-pound patties are served on excellent brioche buns, with a staggering array of toppings, sauces and delicious combos. Larkburger , with several Colorado locations including one outside Vail, also uses high-quality 1/3-pound patties, but ups the ante with fine dining touches such as homemade mayo — four kinds — plus locally grown tomatoes, excellent hand-cut fries, and sides like edamame. It’s fast food done as well as you can do it.
USA TODAY
No beef: Park City saloon specializes in bison burgers
USA TODAY
Top-shelf distillery, decadent desserts delight Park City visitors
USA TODAY
Great American Bites: A tasty ski-town burger in Breckenridge
USA TODAY
Larkburger: Building a better burger, Colorado-style
Salt Lake City, gateway to half a dozen world-class Utah resorts, has a uniquely Greek-influenced burger scene with two standout family-owned local chains. Crown Burger specializes in a patty topped with moist, broth-soaked Greek-style pastrami while Apollo Burger makes the delicious and decadent Athenian, with feta cheese, roasted red peppers, and a standout house tzatziki sauce.
USATODAY
Great American Bites: Crown Burger, Salt Lake City - USATODAY.com
USA TODAY
Rave review: Athenian burger at Utah's Apollo chain
Salt Lake is also home to perhaps the best Mexican eatery in all of skiing, the famed Red Iguana , with three locations and a huge menu, best known for its array of seven different delicious, authentic and often very spicy takes on mole sauce. Another great choice for South of the Border cuisine is Zocalito in Aspen, Colo., hidden underneath a back alley and focused on the food of Mexico’s culinary capital Oaxaca, with such authentic offerings as fried grasshoppers.
USA TODAY
Great American Bites: Mexican food in Utah? Red Iguana is the real deal
USA TODAY
Great American Bites: A taste of Oaxaca in high-rent Aspen
For some reason ski resorts do not do a great job with Asian eateries (except for high-end sushi like Matsuhisa in Aspen and Vail), but a very pleasant and offbeat exception is Teton Thai , located near the base of Wyoming’s Jackson Hole. Locally loved, it’s run by a husband and wife team, and she is from Thailand and does the cooking. Despite the crowds, it is well worth the effort. Another unusual choice in the town of Jackson is Bin 22 , a Mediterranean tapas place with a wide variety of affordable and delicious Italian and Spanish inspired small plates, all set within a retail wine shop that sells bottles to drink at dinner with no upcharge, a rarity that completes a great après ski or dinner experience, and like Teton Thai, it is extremely popular with locals.
USA TODAY
Top-notch tapas and charcuterie take the Tetons
Barbecue is a traditional favorite found in just about every ski town, but unfortunately, it is rarely exceptional. That is what makes Moe’s Original Bar B Que and Oak stand out — they’d stand out anywhere. Moe’s is an Alabama-style chain founded by Alabamans that happens to have been born in Vail, Colo., and while there are now thirty in eight states, the original sits a stone’s throw from the Lionshead gondola and serves an amazing boneless rib sandwich, great pulled pork, and delicious shrimp po’ boys. Likewise, Oak sits next to the lifts at the base of Telluride, and is also owned by an Alabama transplant. The pork ribs are fantastic, as is the signature app, unconventional BLT “wraps” using lettuce leaves and house-cured bacon, all washed down with a deep bourbon and rye list.
USA TODAY
Beyond McRib: Moe's Bar B Que does sparerib sandwich right
USA TODAY
Great American Bites: Ski-town BBQ reaches summit in Telluride
Pizza is another widely available but usually mediocre ski town staple, and again, Telluride has what may well be the nation’s best slopeside offering, the incredible Detroit-style pan version at Brown Dog Pizza . Baked in oiled rectangular metal pans, it’s a cross between Chicago and East Coast, rich and delicious. Because the crust is so exceptional, I recommend only ordering smalls (four slices versus eight) so you get only corners, each with twice the crust. The award-winning 313 (Detroit’s area code) has ricotta, garlic, genoa salami, red Calabrian chili peppers, sweet piquante peppers, fresh basil, and arugula. The East Coast has more standalone mountains and fewer true ski towns, but skiers can still find standout and unique pizza at American Flatbread in Waitsfield, Vt., near both the Sugarbush and Mad River Glen resorts. American Flatbread is now sold frozen nationwide, but it is much better at the source and this is the original location (there is also one in downtown Burlington, the main gateway to Vermont skiing). It features a sort of focaccia-like crust cooked in wood burning ovens, with impeccably sourced natural and unprocessed toppings like nitrate-free peperoni and sausages made of natural pork from a local farm.
USA TODAY
OMG! Detroit-style pizza delivers taste sensation
USATODAY
Great American Bites: American Flatbread's unique take on pizza
Yum! Enjoy ski season.
Larry Olmsted has been writing about food and travel for more than 15 years. An avid eater and cook, he has attended cooking classes in Italy, judged a barbecue contest and once dined with Julia Child. Follow him on Twitter, @TravelFoodGuy , and if there's a unique American eatery you think he should visit, send him an email at travel@usatoday.com . Some of the venues reviewed by this column provided complimentary services.
